customer_addr:
2976 E. State St Suite 120 #211
Eagle, ID 83616

citations.narrative:
On July 30, 2024 guests opened both doors of the walk-in aviary’s double-door system simultaneously which allowed one
free flying parakeet to escape the atrium. The escapee flew over the open topped aquarium which shares a wall with the
aviary. The attendant witnessed a large black Pacu fish measuring approximately 2 feet in length breach the water’s
surface, catch the bird in flight, and eat it. Housing facilities must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally
sound for the species of bird housed in them, employ measures that contain all birds securely, and protect the birds from
injury. Birds that are not protected from escape, hazards, or predation may suffer from stress, injury, or death.
Correct by September 15, 2024 by ensuring that bird enclosures are designed, constructed, and maintained in good
repair for the species of bird housed in them; protect the birds from injury; and security measures are employed to contain
all birds securely to prevent escape of the birds.

Three parakeets in the walk-in aviary were killed when stepped on by guests. Guests are allowed to enter the atrium to
feed a seed mixture from their hands to the free flying parakeets. During feeding, some seed falls on the ground and the
birds land on the ground to get the seed putting them at risk of injury. Birds have been stepped on and died on three
separate occasions as follows:
***On March 9, 2024 a special needs child feeding the birds became overly stimulated, began jumping up and down, and
spilled their handful of seed. Before the attendant could intervene to escort them away from the birds, the child jumped on
a bird, killing it.
***On July 31, 2024 a guest with a toddler was participating in the feeding of the parakeets. Guests are informed that
toddlers must be held in the parents’ arms. Despite being informed of the rule, a guest visiting this day set their toddler on
the floor to walk around and the toddler stepped on a bird.
***On August 24, 2024 during a feeding encounter an attendant saw a bird abruptly start circling on the ground with its
wings spread out. The bird died shortly after it started circling. The guest nearest to this bird quickly stated that they did
not step on the bird. The facility representative presumes the bird was stepped on by the guest considering the sudden
onset of symptoms and the reaction of the guest.
Correct by September 15, 2024 by ensuring that there is minimal risk of harm to the birds during public exhibition. The
facility must take measures to ensure safe handling with sufficient distance and/or barriers between the birds and the
general viewing public to assure the health and safety of all animals.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.150(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, general. 
On July 30, 2024 guests opened both doors of the walk-in aviary’s double-door system simultaneously which allowed one 
free flying parakeet to escape the atrium. The escapee flew over the open topped aquarium which shares a wall with the 
aviary. The attendant witnessed a large black Pacu fish measuring approximately 2 feet in length breach the water’s 
surface, catch the bird in flight, and eat it. Housing facilities must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally 
sound for the species of bird housed in them, employ measures that contain all birds securely, and protect the birds from 
injury. Birds that are not protected from escape, hazards, or predation may suffer from stress, injury, or death.  
 
Correct by September 15, 2024 by ensuring that bird enclosures are designed, constructed, and maintained in good 
repair for the species of bird housed in them; protect the birds from injury; and security measures are employed to contain 
all birds securely to prevent escape of the birds. 
2.131(c)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
Three parakeets in the walk-in aviary were killed when stepped on by guests. Guests are allowed to enter the atrium to 
feed a seed mixture from their hands to the free flying parakeets. During feeding, some seed falls on the ground and the 
birds land on the ground to get the seed putting them at risk of injury. Birds have been stepped on and died on three 
separate occasions as follows: 
***On March 9, 2024 a special needs child feeding the birds became overly stimulated, began jumping up and down, and 
spilled their handful of seed. Before the attendant could intervene to escort them away from the birds, the child jumped on 
a bird, killing it.  
***On July 31, 2024 a guest with a toddler was participating in the feeding of the parakeets. Guests are informed that 
toddlers must be held in the parents’ arms. Despite being informed of the rule, a guest visiting this day set their toddler on 
the floor to walk around and the toddler stepped on a bird. 
***On August 24, 2024 during a feeding encounter an attendant saw a bird abruptly start circling on the ground with its 
wings spread out. The bird died shortly after it started circling. The guest nearest to this bird quickly stated that they did 
not step on the bird. The facility representative presumes the bird was stepped on by the guest considering the sudden 
onset of symptoms and the reaction of the guest.

Correct by September 15, 2024 by ensuring that there is minimal risk of harm to the birds during public exhibition. The 
facility must take measures to ensure safe handling with sufficient distance and/or barriers between the birds and the 
general viewing public to assure the health and safety of all animals. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
